hints_html:
Parts a) - d) have each told you something about how the function should appear when you sketch it:

Does the function have a discontinuity? (see part a)

Does the function has have any vertical asymptotes or approach any points/lines as x gets large? (see part b)

Does the function have any maxima/minima? (see part c)

What is the concavity of the function? (see part d)

Parts a) - d) have each told you something about how the function should
appear when you sketch it:

Does the function have a discontinuity? (see part a)

Does the function has have any vertical asymptotes or approach any
points/lines as x gets large? (see part b)

Does the function have any maxima/minima? (see part c)

What is the concavity of the function? (see part d)

Parts a) - d) have each told you something about how the function should appear when you sketch it:

Does the function have a discontinuity? (see part a)

Does the function has have any vertical asymptotes or approach any points/lines as x gets large? (see part b)

Does the function have any maxima/minima? (see part c)

What is the concavity of the function? (see part d)
question: 4 (e)
sols_html:
From parts a) - d), we found that

[1] f is continous everywhere

[2] There is a horizontal asymptote of \(y = 2\) for \(x \rightarrow \infty\).

[3] There is a local max at (0,2) and a local min at (1,1)

[4] There are no inflection points at f is concave down everywhere except at x = 0, x = 1.

From this information we can obtain an image that looks similar to this:
sols_latex:
From parts a) - d), we found that

{[}1{]} f is continous everywhere

{[}2{]} There is a horizontal asymptote of $y = 2$ for
$x \rightarrow \infty$.

{[}3{]} There is a local max at (0,2) and a local min at (1,1)

{[}4{]} There are no inflection points at f is concave down everywhere
except at x = 0, x = 1.

From this information we can obtain an image that looks similar to this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2010/MATH100_2010_4e.png}
sols_raw:
From parts a) - d), we found that

[1] f is continous everywhere

[2] There is a horizontal asymptote of <math>y = 2</math> for <math>x \rightarrow \infty</math>.

[3] There is a local max at (0,2) and a local min at (1,1)

[4] There are no inflection points at f is concave down everywhere except at x = 0, x = 1.

From this information we can obtain an image that looks similar to this:

[[File:MATH100 2010 4e.png]]
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Let

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{4}{\pi} \tan^{-1} x & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\ 2-x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

NOTE: Another notation for tan-1(x) is arctan(x)

Sketch the curve y = \(f(x)\), showing all the features given in items (a) to (d) above and giving the (x, y) coordinates for all points occurring above (if any).
statement_latex:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show
all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there.
Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Let

\begin{align*}
f(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{4}{\pi} \tan^{-1} x & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\
2-x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 
\end{cases}
\end{align*}

NOTE: Another notation for \emph{tan}\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{x}) is
\emph{arctan}(\emph{x})

Sketch the curve \emph{y} = $f(x)$, showing all the features given
in items (a) to (d) above and giving the (\emph{x}, \emph{y})
coordinates for all points occurring above (if any).
statement_raw:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Let 

:<math>
f(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{4}{\pi} \tan^{-1} x & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\
2-x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 
\end{cases}
</math>

NOTE: Another notation for ''tan''<sup>-1</sup>(''x'') is ''arctan''(''x'')

Sketch the curve ''y'' = &fnof;(''x''), showing all the features given in items (a) to (d) above and giving the (''x'', ''y'') coordinates for all points occurring above (if any).
